I'm really excited to be here. It's a privilege to be here
among this fantastic HCI

community, who've been
pushing the boundaries of HCI for many, many years, and to be
among this young new generation

of HCI enthusiasts who are going
to build the future of HCI.

So I'm excited to talk to
you about my current work on harnessing data for
social good or social impact,

empowering communities
through visualization and social computing.

As Michael said very
correctly, my pronunciation is Narges Mahyar, my
name pronunciation.

And currently, I'm at Harvard
as a Harvard Radcliffe fellow, but I'm at UMass Amherst, and
I'm co-founder and co-director

of HCI-VS Lab at UMass. Speaking of the
lab, Ali Sarvghad

and I established a lab in 2020
with only two PhD students.

And I'm so proud
to see the lab has been growing with having
more than 24 active members

and many alumni. And we focus on research on
socially impactful technologies

that empower data-informed
decision-making. You can see the website for
more information on our projects

and people and publications. The structure of
my talk for today is I'll start by presenting
a short introduction

about my work, motivating
my work, and where I am and what I'm doing. And then I'll briefly talk
about a few selected projects,

and finally, I'll
describe my vision for future work and
a call to action,

and with that, I
hope I can inspire you to join our team to
make this vision a reality

through collaboration. In terms of research, we are a
very interdisciplinary research

lab. We conduct both fundamental
as well as applied research at the intersection of
visualization, social computing,

design, and more
and more nowadays, applied machine learning and AI.

However, HCI or
human-centered computing serves as the
overarching principle

that shapes all of my
work within a very deeply human-centered framework.

And with our work
with community, we extend the
human-centered computing to community-centered
computing when

we try to understand the needs
and challenges of community and design and build
technology for them.

In terms of domain area, I've
been working on urban planning and placemaking, building
tools and technology

for bringing people to
these very complex matters. I have built several
partnerships with city or town

officials and groups across
Vancouver, British Columbia

to San Diego, Amherst,
and nowadays Boston. Also, text visual
analytics is another domain

that I've been working on,
and financial data analysis. And nowadays, more and
more on building technology

for bringing awareness and
education around climate change.

To give you an idea of
where I'm coming from and the research areas
that I'm been working on,

here are the main directions of
my research with some selected work. So visual analytics
was the focus of my PhD

where you might be able to
look at those small thumbnails and see large interactive
surfaces where I was building

technology and visual
analytics tools, enabling a group of experts and analysts
go through complex data

and solve it collaboratively
and more effectively. And nowadays we're still
working with visual analytics,

but with the focus of
increasing the coverage of data, and basically balancing
and mitigating

biases in the analysis process. Until a month before, I used to
say during the past nine years,

but now I can say during
the past decade, I've been-- and shifted my
focus on addressing

complex socio-technical
problems. And my team and I have
been building and studying

what I call community-centered
tools for increasing public engagement in massive
civic decision-making processes.

And today, I'm mostly going
to focus on this line of work, but I'm happy to chat offline
about any other line of my work.

Another line of my work is what
I like to call visualization for empowerment.

And by that, I mean,
building visualization tools

and making data
visualization and analysis accessible for empowering
a broader audience,

including the general public
to understand and explore the data that is increasingly
part of their lives,

and we've seen it during
the COVID pandemic and many other
situations where people

need visualization to
make informed decisions, personally or collectively.

Speaking of
sociotechnical problems as Don Norman and Staper
write in this article,

sociotechnical
problems are complex, multifaceted problems that
are difficult to solve

due to their interconnectedness
and shifting natures, making them very difficult
to sort out cause and effect

and solve. Examples are systems such as
healthcare or transportation

or governmental policy and
environmental protection and sustainability.

They're also known
as wicked problem. Anybody has heard of
wicked problem before?

Lovely. In this classic article,
Rittel and Webber in 1973

coined the term wicked
problem and they talked about complex problems
such as planning problems

and their wickedness, and how
and why they're difficult. So they defined 10
different characteristics

of wicked problems, but
mainly they are unstructured.

They're difficult to
out cause and effect, and therefore there are more
difficult than other type

of problems to solve. They crosscutting, meaning
they have a lot of overlapping

different objectives
different orientation, and therefore it becomes a
very messy and very conflicting

space to be able
to solve a problem. And they're relentless. They can't be solved
once and for all.

Whatever decision that you
make makes one group unhappy while it makes the
other group happy.

It's very, very difficult. So
one way to tame wicked problem

is to engage all the
stakeholders in community. So community engagement
is really the key

because it helps
to raise awareness. A lot of time the
community itself do not have awareness or
education about those problems,

and it causes a lot of
tension and friction. To tap into their
local knowledge,

they have a lot of
valuable knowledge that the policymakers and
decision-makers don't know,

and then ultimately it
encourages collaboration and co-creation among
all of these stakeholders

to come up with viable solution. There is a big
problem here though.

Community engagement has been
a problem for over a century, especially in the US.

So in this article
Innes and Booher talk about how conventional
public engagement, especially

in the US, and especially
public hearings review and comment
procedures not only do not

meet the most basic goals
for public participation, but they're also
counterproductive.

They cause anger
mistrust and even revolt. Anybody has been to a
public meeting before?

Yes, a handful. As you as you might have
seen, similar to this picture, only a handful of people get to
stand up and raise their voice

and bring their comments. But many others who
have already invested coming to these
meetings do not get

to share their ideas
and feedback, which is a big problem. So I want to mention
that there are so

many different challenges
around public engagement and public participation. In this talk, I refer to some
of the main or grand challenges

that my research has
been trying to address. First is enhancing engagement of
the participants, the ones who

are already engaged
enough to make it to a public meeting
or workshop, but there is no means to further and more
meaningfully engaging them.

Engaging reticent participants. Again, the ones that
are actively engaged,

who made it to those
public hearing, but as we just spoke during
those town hall meetings,

they don't get to speak
up, and they remain silent. Scaling participation, which has
been the very big quest of mine,

how we can scale participation
beyond those white affluent educated publications,
populations who are usually

part of these meetings. And then another big
and more underexplored

problem is how to
record and analyze these what I call
precious public inputs

and utilize them in the
actual decisions at the end. These are the selected
projects that I'm

going to go over briefly
today, and each of them is trying to, at least,
address one of the problems

that I just mentioned. So let's start with UD
Co-Spaces for enhancing engagement of participants.

UD Co-Spaces is short for Urban
Design Collaborative Spaces, and as you can see
through this picture

it's a tabletop-centered,
multidisplay environment for engaging the public
in the very complex matter

of urban design. This was a long-term
interdisciplinary project between computer science and
architecture department at UBC,

where I worked as a postdoc. As a postdoc coming to
this very new field,

I started delving
into to the literature to understand like urban studies
and the computational support.

And the more I
delved, the more I found there is a lack of tool
support during these design--

charrettes or design, active
participation meeting, especially for integrating data
and visualization of information

to enable people to understand
more tangibly what they're talking about, to employ those
interactive modes to engage

people more interactively, and
then employing social and peer learning, which we all know
is very important for bringing

people to these areas. And the absence of visualization
and computer support tools

for planning and
public engagement marked a turning point in my
career 10 years ago, that makes

an inspired a shift in my focus
towards the development of tools for this domain.

Therefore, our
research questions were around how to build
collaborative technology

and visualization
techniques to engage diverse set of stakeholders
to foster collaboration

and co-creation among them, and
more importantly, to increase their understanding of the
impact of their design choices.

So here is the
tabletop interface. At each corner,
there is a case bar

where the user can explore
different buildings which they call them cases
in urban planning,

and they can get their
information whenever they're ready with their choice. They can simply drag and
drop it on an interactive map

on the table. They can position
it where they want. And then the spatial
results are displayed in 3D

on a project on the wall to
enable them to see in a better

way, and there are
handheld devices that are connected to
this ecosystem that enables first remote interaction
with the table with a wall

display. And we also built a
visualization dashboard that allows people to
choose and drag and drop

in a very simple
interaction manner the metrics or indicators
of urban design

that matters and is more
important for the team. And it's all
basically as you might

be able to see dynamically
change as people adding more to their design of
the map on the table.

We conducted a formal
evaluation which

I'm now going
through the detail, but we compared our digital
tool versus a formal paper--

a paper-based
version, and we try to make them as similar
as possible in terms of the map, the highlights, the
building information that we

gave to each team
member, and so on, and some interesting results
in a very summary format.

One very interesting
observation was that the tabletop and
this digital ecosystem

increased the equity of
access to design materials.

What do I mean? In a paper-based version,
we saw some people guarding their
design just like this

because either they had more
knowledge of urban design than other team members, or
they didn't want anyone to mess

with their perfect design. The time was short, versus
in the digital form, it was so easy to do and redo
and to see and discuss together

as a team, and finally
come up with a decision. As one of the participants
said, having this tabletop

got every stakeholder involved,
so they can make changes themselves, see those
changes right away,

which promotes collaboration. Another observation was the
multidisplay environment

catalyzed discussion. We observed many instances where
the team members were looking at the wall and the 3D
explaining and going through how

this neighborhood is going to
look like with these new builds and one said I definitely really
liked how everything was synced,

especially with regards to
3D, iPad, and table itself. But most importantly, one
of our goals in this project

was to bring the
ability of visualization to enhance people's
visual analytics,

and also to add a personal
space in this very shared

collaborative space to enable
people to basically look at the data in their
own time, while adding

those iPads to this ecosystem. And as you might be able to
see through this picture,

we saw many instances when
people were looking and checking their metrics on the iPad, and
they were adjusting their design

accordingly. And based on our results,
the digital group came up with more informed
decisions afterwards

due to having this
analytical dashboard. One said having indicators
in real time definitely

altered how we
approach the project, we could see the larger impact.

So in terms of
implication, there are a lot of implications
of this project. One was this multitouch
and natural interaction

which just drag and drop and
rotate and zoom and all of this. It was really, really
successful for broadening

participation and engagement. So it can definitely be used in
other domains such as education,

and whenever you want
to bring a broader audience to understanding
and working with technology.

and we had visitors
from high schools. All of them learned how to use
the system in less than five

minutes which was a really,
really good news for such a complex tool.

And then having that personal
space within a shared workspace was really, really the key and
important because the version

before didn't have
the personal space, and we saw different results. We also wrote this paper--

this is a short workshop
paper, but we talk about form factor matters and all
of other design criteria

for building
multidisciplinary environment from the angle to size to
rotation to everything.

Also one very interesting matter
for me coming from visualization perspective was how
using those infographics

that you show very
briefly during that demo was helpful for conveying
sustainability metrics.

So here's another
picture of those. We had a team of
multimedia design students

over summer who designed
all of these infographics in the middle of
those donut charts

to be able to convey
a lot of these metrics without much labeling, and
it was very, very effective.

It was so effective that
it sparked my interest to run an actual experiments and
scientific study to understand

whether or not
infographics hinder or doesn't hinder or maybe
improve people's understanding

because there has been
some connotations, negative connotations
around infographics in the visualization community.

And the good news was the
infographic helped people

to envision the topic
better without sacrificing, understanding, comparing to
the abstract visualization.

So with that, I'm going to
move to the next project which

is community. Click for engaging
reticent participants.

And it's a system for
capturing and reporting community feedback from town
halls to improve inclusivity.

We called it CommunityClick
because we basically brought iClickers to town hall
with one important modification,

and that was making the
feedback in real time. So you don't have to
pull people at any--

they can bring their
feedback at any given time. And this is based on the success
factor of iClickers in education

which has shown to
increase students engagement with the material. This was the work of my former
PhD student, Mahmoud Jassim

along with two master's
students Amy Zong and Ali Sadat. So again back to our picture
and town hall meetings,

there are common
methods still in the US for hearing from the
public, understanding

their requirements,
needs and issues. Ideally, you would
want all the attendees

in such meetings to
bring their comments and ideas and suggestions
and questions,

but only a handful get to
bring their ideas due to fear

of public speaking,
fear of confrontation, language barriers,
shortage of time,

and so many other barriers. Furthermore, the
organizers struggle

to facilitate the meeting and
capture attendees feedback at the same time, and they
have to run the meeting,

manage discussion, collect data,
sometimes resolve conflict, and as a result of all of
those activities, a lot of time

those precious public input
gets lost during this process, and doesn't get utilized
in the actual decisions.

With that, our
research questions were focused on addressing
these two problems.

How do we empower attendees,
in particular those silent fractions to express
their opinion,

and how can we enable
organizers to come up with more comprehensive
reports at the end?

So here are some different
set of iClickers that we use. As you can see, we
have labeled them.

The blue one was for organizers
to say here's a main issue

or here's a new idea that

I agree or disagree or I

right at this moment now

I guess, or this is

that we've done with
both communities, and we created the
iClicker recorder

to basically record all
the input in real time.

And then here I want to show you
the workflow of community click,

which basically we gather
all of the meeting attendees through iClickers as

and we use off-the-shelf

into our visual analytic
interface, which offers a wide range of features

content and generating
comprehensive report. So here's how it looks like. As I said, it has
several components.

They're all interlinked
and interactive, and provides a wide
array of features.

Here are some main features. For example, the organizers

For example, you

you say, I want to

We also built this

For example, you're

meeting for that chunk

We deployed community clinic in

CommunityCrit was
inspired by crowdsourcing methods to engage
the public at scale,

and enable them to improve
and evaluate ideas, rather than just
merely proposing ideas.

And this was part of
my postdoc project at UC San Diego
with Stephen Dow.

To give you some background
about other tools for public participation,
this is PlanYourPlace,

which was built for
everyday citizen with this easy-to-use

But the author
themselves found it after evaluation hard
for everyday citizen

to understand and
use the system. There are also
crowdsourcing tools

which are fairly easy
for the public to use. For example, this one
is called WikiSurvey, which has been
deployed in many cities

like Chicago and
New York and so on, and it basically asks
a pairwise question,

and give people ability to bring
their own comments or ideas. However, research shows that
people are tired and fed up

with government asking them

and building those plans. So with those our research
questions were around how can we

create a system for activities
beyond opinion polling that captures quality feedback
in a short amount of time,

knowing that citizens
don't have a lot of time to spare for these matters?

And we began by attending
a local design workshop and planning meetings. We took notes during a street
tour, attended the workshop.

My team is here. I'm actually sitting on the
table, and my team is there.

My intern student, Michelle Ink,
who is now a PhD student here,

was there actually recording all
of the conversations as well. And based on all of
this formative work,

we built CommunityCrit,
which is available online. And in order to lower the
barrier for the public,

it works on a variety of
devices including smartphones, and it starts by
giving people an idea

about the placemaking challenge
that they're talking about. In this case, we were partnering
with a team in San Diego

to redesign San Diego's
downtown neighborhood. But then it gives
a short background

about the design problem. We focus on this
key intersection in downtown San Diego.

And then it structures
a process where participants choose an idea. This idea can come from
those public workshops

where we went to and recorded
all of the ideas or online through our system.

And then it only asks
people five questions for the matter of simplicity. Five questions such as,
critique the idea based

on these certain considerations,
or rating the concept on different dimensions.

And then to collect
meaningful feedback, we provided the option
of skipping questions

if they wanted to. And then they can also submit
their own ideas, give it a name,

and add a picture for
it, and at the end, they see a full set of ideas.

They can repeat this process
as many times as they want. So after deploying the tool
in San Diego for four weeks,

we received 352 contributions
from 39 community members, which

from the planning group we were
working on was a huge, huge win.

And we interviewed people who

so it provides opportunity

were scaling and diversifying

When also people are

So with that, we

And we implemented
an emotion classifier because all of the

It doesn't make sense for us. We want something beyond that. We want to see the
reaction of people. Do they hate it?

Do they love it? Why do they hate it? And so on. And we basically build a
transformer-based bar model

to basically show all
of these emotions here. And then we ran a study
with civic leaders,

and not surprisingly,
all of them started by filtering
based on angry comments.

And again, not
surprisingly, the roundabout was the first proposal

And then if they click on

So basically
provides at a glance an overview of emotions

why they're angry or why

implications of this work

was exactly extracting
community reactions rather than sticking
